Title: Biomarkers of Individual Differences in Human Cortical Visual Processing

This proposal seeks to uncover the physiological and personality-based factors that contribute to individual differences in human visual perception. Despite being the best understood system of the human brain, vision is affected by various factors, leading to significant differences in how people perceive the world. However, the underlying mechanisms driving these differences remain unclear. This project aims to bridge this knowledge gap by investigating how vision is influenced by physiological state and personality traits.

Using a combination of innovative methods, including pupil responses, ultra-high field Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the human visual cortex, and psychophysics, we will examine the relationship between cortical processing, metabolism, and perception in normally sighted individuals, including young children. We predict that behavioral and cortical properties will co-vary with personality traits, and that physiological interventions, such as ketosis induced by fasting and intense physical activity, will modulate perceptual styles.

The proposed research has significant potential impacts, including changing our understanding of pervasive developmental disorders, aiding in the diagnosis of Autistic Spectrum Disorders, and encouraging therapeutic approaches that target general physiology. We expect to identify new reliable biomarkers for local context-independent perception and provide evidence of perceptual style changes within individuals due to metabolic fluctuations. By elucidating the complex relationships between metabolism, cortical processing, and perception, this project will provide new knowledge on the factors driving individual differences in human visual perception.
